abstracts.cdata!:
The project, aimed at providing
            assistance to an existing Government program, only took six
            months to be prepared, coincidentally presented to the Board
            a few months prior to elections. Based on risks identified
            in the Project Appraisal Document of a change in Government,
            with a possible lack of continuity in project objectives,
            and, the necessary flexibility provided in the Project
            design to accommodate changes, the loan was withdrawn at the
            request of the Government of Panama, on March 10, 2000. Key
            policy and institutional reforms with regard to maintenance
            management, environmental and social issues, and the
            reorganization of public passenger transport, will be
            pursued by the Bank through the on-going Road Rehabilitation
            Project, which has been extended until March 30, 2002.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Second Roads
            Rehabilitation Project are: (i) to improve transport
            efficiency on the road network; (ii) to continue reducing
            traffic congestion and providing more efficient, safe, and
            reliable road transport services in Panama city, and other
            major cities in Panama; (iii) to continue the improvement in
            the Ministry of Public Work's capacity for the
            administration and maintenance of roads and of environmental
            impact analysis started under the ongoing Roads
            Rehabilitation Project (Loan 3686-PA); and (iv) to improve
            the efficiency in the public road passenger transport
            industry by fostering more competition. The components
            include: (i) the reduction of high transport costs by the
            road and street rehabilitation component; (ii) the
            alleviation of excessive traffic congestion in Panama City
            by the urban streets and intersections improvement
            component; (iii) road allocation funding to be maintained at
            its currently high levels agreed by the Government as a loan
            covenant; and (iv) the provision of additional technical
            assistance and training to support the development of the
            Environmental Unit (Unidad Ambiental).
